abstract: Sanford I. Weill’s call to break up big banks certainly took many on Wall Street by surprise. But it was such a major Damascene conversion that at least one longtime banking grandee, Alan C. Greenberg, thinks it’s unbelievable.
snippet: Sanford I. Weill’s call to break up big banks certainly took many on Wall Street by surprise. But it was such a major Damascene conversion that at least one longtime banking grandee, Alan C. Greenberg, thinks it’s unbelievable.
lead_paragraph: Sanford I. Weill’s call to break up big banks certainly took many on Wall Street by surprise. But it was such a major turnabout that at least one longtime banking grandee thinks it’s unbelievable.

headline.main: Greenberg Asks: Was That Sandy Weill, or Sacha Baron Cohen?

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced
